statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Tyler Newton made two late free throws to help Pacific (No. 16 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) win its 22nd straight game, a 63-61 victory over Cal State Northridge on Friday night in the Big West semifinals.
article.headline: Tigers struggle, but reach Big West final
article.linkText: No. 16 Pacific gets scare, but runs streak to 22
article.story:
ANAHEIM, Calif. (AP) -- Pacific withstood its biggest scare in
weeks and kept the nation's longest winning streak alive.

Tyler Newton made two late free throws to help Pacific (No. 16 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) win its 22nd straight game, a 63-61 victory over Cal State
Northridge on Friday night in the Big West semifinals.

Guillaume Yango had 15 points and eight rebounds for the Tigers,
who ran their Big West streak to 34 games.

Pacific (26-2) will play Utah State or Cal State Fullerton in
the title game Saturday night.

Christian Maraker added 13 points, and Newton finished with 12
for the top-seeded Tigers, seeking their second straight conference
title.

Pacific led by as many as 12 in the second half, but Joseph
Frazier gave the fourth-seeded Matadors (17-13) their first lead
since early in the first half with a steal and a layup that made it
61-60 with a minute to play.

Newton's two free throws with 22 seconds left gave Pacific a
62-61 lead.

Ian Boylan scored a career-high 32 points for Northridge, but
missed a short jumper with 9.1 seconds left.

Jasko Korajkic then made one of two free throws, and Frazier
missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer.

"We were very fortunate tonight,'' Pacific coach Bob Thomason
said. "Hopefully, this is a big-time scare that can get us back on
track. We made some mistakes, we got away with it. It's been that
way all year.''

Pacific had 23 turnovers.

The two-point margin was the Tigers' closest since a 64-63
victory over Utah State on Feb. 12.

Yango had a three-point play to give Pacific its biggest lead,
56-44 with 8:19 to play.

But Boylan kept Northridge in the game, making a 3-pointer with
5:53 to play and another with 3:46 to go to bring the Matadors
within three at 57-54.

Boylan scored 19 of his points in the second half, and also had
seven steals.

"Boylan is a great player,'' Thomason said. "We had no answer
for him.''

The 22-game winning streak is the longest in Pacific history.

The Tigers are taking nothing for granted, assuming that
they have to win the tournament for an NCAA Tournament berth.

Last year, Utah State was denied an at-large bid despite a 25-4
record and a top 25 ranking after losing in the semifinals Big West
tournament.

"I don't think being in or not being in is going to affect how
we play. These other teams really want to go to the NCAAs, too.''

Pacific used a 17-2 run, completed by a layup from Maraker, to
take a 26-11 lead with 7:15 to play in the first half. Matt
Kemper's tip-in with 6 seconds to go in the half gave Pacific a
34-24 lead at halftime.
